title: External Services
description:
External Services


The existing external rtpproxy set up is not usable for any practical purposes, because all rtp goes in a single thread. The Sippy Media Gateway is the solution for your external media relaying requirements.


External Services is a feature allowing to off-load parts of the traffic processing to separate servers, effectively building a distributed cluster. This feature could be used in order to optimize media path as well as to increase maximum system throughput and make system more robust.

At the moment, only supported external service is media relay, known as RTPproxy and the Sippy Media Gateway.


Adding external media gateway:

  1. Prepare the remote machine.
  • Download RTPproxy at www.rtpproxy.org or use pre-built package for your operating system if available or contact sales@sippysoft.com for the fully supported Sippy Media Gateway.
  • Build and install RTPproxy (skip this step if you are using the pre-built package).
  • Run RTPproxy in the remote control mode using the following command: 

          $ rtpproxy -l <server_ip> -s udp:<server_ip>:<control_port> -F -L 19999


       Where <server_ip> is an IP address of the machine that will be used to run RTPproxy on, and <control_port> is UDP port

       number that the RTPproxy will use to listen for connections from the Sippy Softswitch.


     2. Add corresponding External Service entry on Sippy Softswitch, setting up Service Type to RTPproxy, Hostname to   

        <server_ip> and Port to <control_port>.

     3. Assign the newly created RTPproxy external service as Preferred Media Relay in connections and routing groups. The  

        system will monitor connectivity between the softswitch and external media proxy and fall back to using internal one if the 

        connection fails for some reason.

     4. It also recommended that you configure firewall to only allow UDP packets originated from Sippy Softswitch to be passed to

        the RTPproxy, as RTPproxy doesn't have any access control functionality on itself, where the Sippy Media Gateway does.
